TITLE: Sports and Fashion Won Big Together This Year
SUMMARY: When the teams are brands and the brands are stars and the fans are consumers, everything blends into one enormous business opportunity.

TITLE: Caroline Ellison and FTX Co-Founder Gary Wang Plead Guilty to Fraud
SUMMARY: Caroline Ellison, the former chief executive of Alameda Research, and Gary Wang, a founder of FTX, are cooperating in the federal criminal case against Mr. Bankman-Fried.

TITLE: I.R.S. Routinely Audited Obama and Biden, Raising Questions Over Delays for Trump
SUMMARY: The revelation that the agency had not audited Donald J. Trump during his first two years in office despite a mandatory presidential audit program raised concerns about potential politicization.

TITLE: Under Armour Hires Stephanie Linnartz as CEO
SUMMARY: Stephanie Linnartz will become chief executive of the sportswear giant after its stock has fallen and some of its customer base has strayed.

TITLE: How New I.R.S. Rules Could Affect Venmo, Etsy and Cash App Users
SUMMARY: Some users of digital wallets and e-commerce platforms must start reporting small transactions, sowing fears among small-business owners.

TITLE: For Many Wall Street Bankers, This Year’s Bonus Season Is a Bust
SUMMARY: There were fewer mergers and public listings this year, shrinking investment banking revenue. For bankers, that means a smaller pot of money for bonuses.

TITLE: BlackRock’s Pitch for Socially Conscious Investing Antagonizes All Sides
SUMMARY: Right-wing officials are attacking BlackRock for overstepping. Those on the left say the world’s biggest asset manager is not doing enough.

TITLE: France Desperately Needs Workers, but the Fixes Could Anger Left and Right
SUMMARY: Legalization of undocumented workers and pared-down unemployment benefits are part of the government’s plan to fill hundreds of thousands of jobs.

TITLE: Jeep Plant Shutdown Imperils Illinois Town and 1,350 Workers
SUMMARY: Stellantis plans to idle the factory, which makes the Cherokee, as it shifts to electric vehicles. Labor talks and a union election may be affected.

TITLE: Consumer Spending Cooled in November as Closely Watched Inflation Gauge Slowed
SUMMARY: The Personal Consumption Expenditures index showed prices increased 5.5 percent last month, as consumer spending pulled back.

TITLE: Sam Bankman-Fried Released on $250 Million Bond
SUMMARY: The disgraced cryptocurrency executive appeared in court in Manhattan after his extradition from the Bahamas. He will live with his parents in California.

TITLE: She Worked for Twitter. Then She Tweeted at Elon Musk.
SUMMARY: Sasha Solomon, a software engineer, joined others in the media business who lost their jobs this year after publicly taking on their employers.

TITLE: I.R.S. Delays Tax Change for Users of Venmo, Cash App and Other Digital Wallets
SUMMARY: Users who receive income through digital payments will have another year before having to comply with a new tax rule that had sown confusion and concern.

TITLE: Alberto Zamperla, Amusement Park Impresario, Is Dead at 71
SUMMARY: His family-friendly company revived historic Luna Park in Coney Island and built attractions for Disney and Six Flags.

TITLE: Sam Bankman-Fried Due Back in Court in January, Faces ‘Epic’ Legal Battle
SUMMARY: The disgraced crypto entrepreneur was freed on $250 million bond, but is due back in court in early January on federal fraud charges.

TITLE: As Cases Explode, China’s Low Covid Death Toll Convinces No One
SUMMARY: China’s murky statistics are fueling widespread public distrust. Its narrow definition of Covid deaths “will very much underestimate the true death toll,” the W.H.O. says.

TITLE: At German Christmas Markets, Smiles Shine Bright but Budgets Are Tight
SUMMARY: In Nuremberg, the stalls are open without Covid restrictions, and big crowds are returning to sip mulled wine and socialize. But amid economic uncertainty, visitors are spending less.

TITLE: Human Artists on New A.I. Illustrations
SUMMARY: “Usually what happens is it devalues that human labor.” Three illustrators discuss art generated by artificial intelligence.

TITLE: How to Travel the World While Putting Nature First
SUMMARY: In the wake of the U.N. biodiversity conference, Julia Simpson, the head of the World Travel and Tourism Council, discusses a new initiative called nature positive travel.

TITLE: It’s Boom Times for Santa
SUMMARY: Like other in-person workers, Santa took a hit the first two years of the pandemic. But he’s back in a big way.

TITLE: How Taylor Swift Got Fans to Sign Up for Their First Credit Cards
SUMMARY: For some fans, a chance to see their favorite artists in concert is the most compelling reason to sign up for their first credit cards and start building credit.

TITLE: Britain’s Soaring Energy Costs Strain Crisis Responders
SUMMARY: Families in chilly, drafty homes are seeking help. The response may be a blanket and thick socks, while some doctors are writing prescriptions for heat.

TITLE: What Happened to Bright Starts Beaming Buggie Take-Along Toy?
SUMMARY: The life cycle of a magical baby-soothing toy.

TITLE: Caroline Ellison Says She Is ‘Truly Sorry’ for Her Role in FTX Collapse
SUMMARY: Caroline Ellison of Alameda, a trading firm tied closely to FTX, admitted she participated in defrauding customers and misleading investors.

TITLE: How the Spending Bill’s New Retirement Rules Will Affect Roth IRAs and 401(k)s
SUMMARY: Want to transfer money from a 529 plan to a Roth I.R.A. or get an after-tax employee match in your Roth 401(k)? You may be in luck.

TITLE: Reasons for Optimism in 2023
SUMMARY: Even in a world facing many challenges, there are reasons to be hopeful about next year and beyond.

TITLE: Betting Apps Can Make Anyone a Sports Fan. Even Me.
SUMMARY: One in five Americans bet on sports this year. Against most odds — my total lack of interest in all professional athletics — I was one of them. And I was hooked.

TITLE: Sister Patricia Daly, 66, Dies; Took On Corporate Giants on Social Justice
SUMMARY: A leader in the field of socially responsible investing, she used shareholder actions and private meetings to pressure big corporations, including G.E. and Ford.

TITLE: Germany’s Energy Crisis Is a Cue to Chop Wood and Stock Up
SUMMARY: The high cost of natural gas and electricity is prompting many to prepare for outages and shortages. For some, it’s been a way of life for years.

TITLE: The Week in Business: Who Comes After Elon Musk?
SUMMARY: Mr. Musk said that he would resign as Twitter’s chief executive once he found a successor “foolish enough to take the job.” YouTube reaches deal for the rights to stream N.F.L.’s Sunday Ticket games. And Mark Zuckerberg appears in court in an antitrust hearing.

TITLE: Don Christopher, Who Turned Lowly Garlic Into a Staple, Dies at 88
SUMMARY: Known as the Garlic King, he used his enthusiasm and a business acumen to build an empire around the once-lowly “stinking rose.”

TITLE: Pandemic Woes Lead Met Opera to Tap Endowment and Embrace New Work
SUMMARY: Facing tepid ticket sales, the company will withdraw up to $30 million from its endowment and stage more operas by living composers, which have been outselling the classics.

TITLE: China to Drop Covid Quarantine for Incoming Travelers
SUMMARY: From Jan. 8, visitors will be required to show only a negative P.C.R. test taken within 48 hours. The restrictions had cut the country off from the rest of the world for nearly three years.

TITLE: In the Bahamas, a Lingering Sympathy for Sam Bankman-Fried
SUMMARY: Residents there have a generous view of the disgraced FTX founder, who has been accused of misusing billions of dollars in customer funds.

TITLE: Investigating the Nord Stream Pipeline Sabotage
SUMMARY: As investigators piece together clues, Russia has quietly taken steps to begin expensive repairs on the giant gas pipeline, complicating theories about who was behind September’s sabotage.

TITLE: With ‘Zero Covid,’ China Proved It’s Good at Control. Governance Is Harder.
SUMMARY: For a powerful government that has bragged about its command of the country, its absence at a moment of crisis has made the public question its credibility.

TITLE: These Women Distillers Are Rising With the American Whiskey Boom
SUMMARY: Before Dry January hits, Andrea Wilson of Michter’s and Nicole Austin of Cascade Hollow discuss how the expansion has affected them, particularly as women in a historically male industry.

TITLE: Phil Washington, Biden’s FAA Nominee, Faces Murky Road to Confirmation
SUMMARY: The nominee, Phillip A. Washington, who has yet to receive a confirmation hearing, has drawn scrutiny over his aviation experience and his involvement in a corruption inquiry.

TITLE: Early Version of Disney’s Mickey Mouse Will Soon Be Public Property
SUMMARY: The version of the iconic character from “Steamboat Willie” will enter the public domain in 2024. But those trying to take advantage could end up in a legal mousetrap.

TITLE: Retirees Are One Reason the Fed Has Given Up on a Big Worker Rebound
SUMMARY: Workers are in short supply three years into the pandemic job market rebound, and officials increasingly think they aren’t coming back.

TITLE: Biden Runs Into Doubts in Labor Ranks After Freight Dispute
SUMMARY: Many union leaders say the Biden White House has delivered on its promises. But its handling of a freight rail dispute has given rise to detractors.

TITLE: Southwest and Other Airlines Cancel Thousands of Flights Across the US
SUMMARY: The company canceled more than 60 percent of its flights on Tuesday and Wednesday, leaving many travelers stranded.

TITLE: Getting Creative With Vacant Office Space: Storage, Gym, Film Set
SUMMARY: Some landlords are skipping residential conversion and instead seeking alternatives that are cheaper and easier to manage.

TITLE: What Would It Take to Turn More Offices Into Housing?
SUMMARY: Vast amounts of empty real estate are a crisis for building owners. But some politicians and business leaders hope they can be converted into something new — and transform downtown neighborhoods.

TITLE: Babies in First Class: Which Side of the Aisle Are You On?
SUMMARY: For some travelers, nothing can kill that premium-cabin buzz quicker than an infant next to them. But for parents, despite the overwhelming opposition (and glaring side-eye), seats in the front of the plane can be golden.

TITLE: Southwest and Other Airline Meltdowns in Recent History
SUMMARY: Flight delays and cancellations over the holiday weekend have left thousands of passengers stranded. Here’s a look at a few other notable episodes like it in recent memory.

TITLE: Thousands Will Live Here One Day (as Long as They Can Find Water)
SUMMARY: In the increasingly dry Southwest, drought and climate change pose a challenge for developers, who need to find creative ways to provide water supply to new communities.

TITLE: Ukraine’s Battered Economy Leaves It More Reliant on Foreign Aid.
SUMMARY: Unable to roll over debt accumulated before the war, Ukraine has paid investors more than it has collected this year, the Central Bank says.

TITLE: The Bull-and-Bear Case for 2023
SUMMARY: The S&P 500 is on pace for its first annual decline since 2018 and its worst performance since 2008. Will markets fall further next year?

TITLE: 10 Restaurant and Food Predictions for 2023
SUMMARY: Briny flavors, high-end Jell-O shots, a fascination with outer space and a concern for Earth will guide our choices. At least that’s what the food forecasters say.

TITLE: Is A.I. the Future of Test Prep?
SUMMARY: Riiid is one of a handful of companies that believe that A.I.’s algorithms are perfectly suited to track student performance and give individualized attention.
